data.title: The Gloria Gaynor Interview [Podcast]
data.meta_description: RnB legend Gloria Gaynor talks about life after 'I Will Survive'. A story of chart success, inner emptiness, spiritual search and personal redemption
data.text:
014 The Gloria Gaynor Interview [Podcast]

She’s sung for popes, presidents and princesses, and released songs that still move a crowd decades after release. Her first single Never Can Say Good-Bye became the first song to reach number one status in Billboard’s newly formed dance music charts. In 1979 she released a song that would become her signature track and an anthem to many—I Will Survive. And thirty albums later, she still has one of the most powerful voices in the business.

Her name is Gloria Gaynor, and in this interview you will hear her story—a story of chart success, inner emptiness, spiritual search and personal redemption.

Click To Listen

https://archive.org/download/Mtt014gloriagaynor/mtt014gloriagaynor.mp3 Podcast: Subscribe in iTunes | Right-click to download | Listen to Other Episodes

In the Interview

In this 2009 Open House interview Gloria and I explore:

Her impoverished childhood and early discovery of her talent

Her ‘fairy tale’ break into the music industry

The New York stage accident that threatened to end her career

The unexpected success of I Will Survive (originally a B-side)

Her fascinating journey to faith

Her subsequent musical journey

Her acceptance as a committed Christian by the gay community

Quotes

‘I had homes and cars and jewellery and furs. I had everything a person would call success, but I felt unfulfilled’ Tweet this

‘I started on a quest to learn what could make a person feel fulfilled when they seemingly already had everything’ Tweet this

‘Musically, I became more responsible for the lyrics that I sang and the kind of subject matter I sang about’ Tweet this

‘Then the Lord said to me, “Here’s what I need you to understand: as long as your music is recorded and performed for my glory and is keeping with my principles, my will, my word and my way, your music is not secular, it is sanctified”‘ Tweet this
